theory_models.main_intro: This page contains the scientific foundation of RheoApp. Here you will find the underlying formulas, interactive visualizations and the interpretation of thermal and viscoelastic models.

tts.intro: The fundamental principle behind TTS is that the rheological response of a polymer at different temperatures is **equivalent**, provided it is corrected with a shift factor $a_T$.
tts.physical_basis_text:
**When temperature changes:**
* **High T**: Chains move faster ‚Üí equivalent to **low frequency**
* **Low T**: Chains move slower ‚Üí equivalent to **high frequency**

**The key insight:**
What you measure at 200¬∞C and 1 rad/s is the same as at 180¬∞C and ~10 rad/s (if the material is thermorheologically simple!)
tts.shift_factor_explanation:
- $a_T$ = Shift factor (dimensionless)
- $a_T > 1$: Shift to higher frequency (lower T)
- $a_T < 1$: Shift to lower frequency (higher T)
- At reference temperature: $a_T = 1$ (no shift)
tts.validity_warning:
The material must be **thermorheologically simple**:

‚úÖ **Required for TPU:**
- Hard segments fully melted (T > Tm + 20K)
- No phase separation during measurement
- No chemical changes (crosslinking, degradation)
- Homogeneous morphology at all measurement temperatures

‚ùå **TTS NOT valid if:**
- Hard-segment crystallization is present
- Phase transitions occur during measurement
- Bi-modal molecular weight distribution evolves with T
tts.protip: **Pro Tip:** The **Van Gurp-Palmen plot** (Tab 2 in the main app) is your best friend to verify whether TTS is valid! Curves should overlap.
tts.demo_show_shifted_help: Toggle between raw data and TTS-corrected data
tts.demo_shifted_success:
‚úÖ TTS Applied!
Data shifted with aT={at:.3f}
tts.demo_unshifted_info:
‚ÑπÔ∏è Raw data (no TTS)
Data at different T do not overlap
tts.demo_annotation_unshifted:
‚ùå Without TTS!
Data at {test_temp}¬∞C is left-shifted
(slower relaxation)
tts.demo_title_unshifted: ‚ùå Without TTS: Data at different T
tts.demo_caption_shifted:
‚úÖ **With TTS (shift factor applied):**
- Data at {test_temp}¬∞C shifted to the right (√ó{at:.2f})
- Both temperatures now fall on the same curve
- This proves the material is thermorheologically simple!
tts.demo_caption_unshifted:
‚ùå **Without TTS (raw data):**
- Data at {test_temp}¬∞C lies LEFT of {ref_temp}¬∞C
- Lower T ‚Üí slower molecular motion ‚Üí curve shifts to low œâ
- Curves do NOT overlap ‚Üí we need TTS!
tts.decision_tree:
```
Start here
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚Üí Van Gurp-Palmen curves overlap?
    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ YES ‚úÖ ‚Üí TTS is very likely valid
    ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ NO ‚ùå ‚Üí Continue to step 2
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚Üí R¬≤ of shift factor fit > 0.95?
    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ YES ‚úÖ ‚Üí TTS possibly valid (but be cautious)
    ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ NO ‚ùå ‚Üí TTS NOT valid, use per-temperature data
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚Üí Multiple crossovers in master curve?
    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ NO (1 crossover) ‚úÖ ‚Üí TTS likely valid
    ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ YES (>1 crossover) ‚ùå ‚Üí Thermorheologically complex, be very careful
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚Üí T_ref > Softening Point?
        ‚îú‚îÄ YES ‚úÖ ‚Üí You are above hard-segment melt
        ‚îî‚îÄ NO ‚ùå ‚Üí Increase T_ref! Crystallization disrupts TTS
```
tts.model_comparison_intro: Different temperature models predict different shift factor trends:
tts.model_comparison_adjust_tip: üí° Adjust parameters to see the effect!
tts.model_comparison_interpretation:
**Interpretation:**
- **Arrhenius** (red): Linear relation, simple model
- **WLF** (blue): Curved behavior, better for polymers near Tg
- Both models intersect at T_ref (log(aT) = 0)
- Differences grow at low/high T

thermal.intro: There are three main models to describe the temperature dependence of shift factors. Each model has its own application range and physical interpretation.
thermal.arrhenius_subtitle: For Simple Fluids and High Temperatures
thermal.arrhenius_params:
- **Ea**: Activation energy (kJ/mol) ‚Äî energy required for a flow event
- **R**: Gas constant (8.314 J/mol¬∑K)
- **T**: Absolute temperature (K)
- **T_ref**: Reference temperature (K)
thermal.arrhenius_when:
‚úÖ **Suitable for:**
- High temperatures (T >> Tg + 100K)
- Simple fluids without glass transition in measurement range
- TPU above ~220¬∞C (fully molten, Arrhenius-like)

‚ùå **NOT suitable for:**
- Temperatures near Tg (WLF works better)
- Strongly curved log(aT) vs 1/T plots
thermal.arrhenius_typical:
- **Ea**: 80‚Äì120 kJ/mol
- **R¬≤**: > 0.95 (otherwise TTS is questionable)
- **High Ea interpretation**: Strong temperature sensitivity (hard to process)
- **Low Ea interpretation**: Weak temperature sensitivity (wide processing window)
thermal.wlf_params:
- **C‚ÇÅ**: Free volume parameter (dimensionless)
- **C‚ÇÇ**: Temperature difference parameter (K or ¬∞C)
- **T_ref**: Reference temperature (usually Tg + 50K)
thermal.wlf_universal:
If T_ref = Tg:
- C‚ÇÅ = 17.4
- C‚ÇÇ = 51.6 K

‚ö†Ô∏è **Note:** These are averages! TPU values may deviate due to:
- Hard-segment crystallization effects
- Bi-phase morphology
- Variation in soft-segment chemistry
thermal.wlf_typical:
| Parameter | Normal Range | What does deviation mean? |
|-----------|--------------|----------------------------|
| **C‚ÇÅ** | 8 ‚Äì 17 | C‚ÇÅ < 5: Atypical (possibly thermorheologically complex) |
|  |  | C‚ÇÅ > 30: Very atypical (check data!) |
| **C‚ÇÇ** | 40 ‚Äì 60 K | C‚ÇÇ < 30K: Possibly wrong T_ref |
|  |  | C‚ÇÇ > 100K: Wide temperature range or phase transitions |
thermal.wlf_negative_warning:
‚ö†Ô∏è **CRITICAL WARNING: Negative C‚ÇÅ Values**

If your WLF fit gives a **negative C‚ÇÅ**, this means:

**Physical Impossibility:**
- Negative C‚ÇÅ violates free volume theory
- This is NOT just a bad fit but a **fundamental problem**

**Cause:**
The material is **thermorheologically COMPLEX** in this temperature range.

**For TPU this usually means:**
1. Hard-segment crystallization not fully melted
2. Phase separation changes with T
3. T_ref lies below the softening point

**Solutions:**
1. Choose T_ref = highest measured temperature
2. Remove lowest temperatures from TTS analysis
3. Use only Arrhenius model
4. Accept that TTS is not fully valid and use parameters only for trends
thermal.wlf_tg_estimation:
**üå°Ô∏è Tg Estimation via WLF:**

If you have a WLF fit with C‚ÇÇ, you can estimate the glass transition temperature:

$$T_g \approx T_{ref} - C_2$$

‚ö†Ô∏è This is a rough estimate ‚Äî always validate with DSC.
thermal.vft_subtitle: Hybrid Model for Broad Temperature Ranges
thermal.vft_params:
- **A**: Constant offset (dimensionless)
- **B**: Strength coefficient (K)
- **T‚ÇÄ**: Vogel temperature ‚Äî theoretical freeze temperature (K)
thermal.vft_relation:
Rule of thumb for many polymers:

$$T_g \approx T_0 + 50K$$
thermal.vft_when:
‚úÖ **Advantages:**
- More flexible than WLF
- Works across wider temperature range
- Can describe both Arrhenius-like and WLF-like behavior

‚ö†Ô∏è **Disadvantages:**
- Sensitive to overfitting (3 parameters)
- Fit may diverge if T‚ÇÄ is close to measurement temperatures
- Harder physical interpretation

**Best practice:**
- Use VFT if you have >5 temperatures
- Compare R¬≤ with WLF
- If similar ‚Üí use WLF (simpler)
thermal.model_comparison_table:
| Aspect | Arrhenius | WLF | VFT |
|---------|------------|-----|-----|
| Parameters | 1 | 2 | 3 |
| Temperature range | High T | Near Tg | Broad |
| Physical basis | Activation energy | Free volume | Hybrid |
| Linearity | Linear in 1/T | Nonlinear | Nonlinear |
| Risk | Underfit | Sensitive | Overfit |
thermal.model_interpretation:
| Observation | Meaning | Action |
|-------------|----------|---------|
| Ea > 120 kJ/mol | Very temperature sensitive | Tight process control needed |
| Ea < 60 kJ/mol | Weak T sensitivity | Robust window |
| C‚ÇÅ < 0 | Alarm ‚Äî complex | Increase T_ref |
| C‚ÇÅ = 8‚Äì17 | Normal | OK |
| R¬≤ < 0.90 | Poor fit | Check TTS validity |

structural.intro: These parameters characterize the molecular architecture and processability of your TPU. They can be read directly from the master curve and have concrete processing implications.
structural.eta0_definition:
The viscosity at infinitely low shear rate (or frequency):

$$\eta_0 = \lim_{\omega \to 0} |\eta^*(\omega)|$$

**In practice:** We extrapolate the complex viscosity curve to œâ ‚Üí 0 using the **Cross model**.
structural.eta0_cross_params:
- **Œ∑‚ÇÄ**: Zero-shear viscosity (target value)
- **œÑ**: Characteristic relaxation time (s)
- **n**: Shear-thinning exponent (typically 0.5‚Äì1.0)
structural.eta0_mw_relation:
For **linear polymers** (no branching):

$$\eta_0 \propto M_w^{3.4}$$

**This means:**
- Doubling Mw ‚Üí Œ∑‚ÇÄ increases about **10√ó**
- 10% Mw decrease ‚Üí **~30% Œ∑‚ÇÄ decrease**

‚ö†Ô∏è **For TPU this is more complex** due to hard/soft segment structure, but the trend remains:

**Œ∑‚ÇÄ is extremely sensitive to Mw changes!**
structural.eta0_typical_table:
| TPU Type | Œ∑‚ÇÄ Range (Pa¬∑s) | Processing Behavior |
|-----------|-----------------|---------------------|
| Soft TPU | 10‚Å¥ ‚Äì 10‚Åµ | Easy processing, low pressure |
| Medium TPU | 10‚Åµ ‚Äì 5√ó10‚Åµ | Normal process window |
| Stiff TPU | 5√ó10‚Åµ ‚Äì 10‚Å∂ | High pressure, tight T window |
| Very stiff | > 10‚Å∂ | Difficult, degradation risk |
structural.eta0_process:
| Process | Role of Œ∑‚ÇÄ | Optimal Œ∑‚ÇÄ Range |
|-----------|------------|------------------|
| Extrusion | Pressure build-up | 10‚Åµ ‚Äì 5√ó10‚Åµ |
| Injection molding | Fill time & pressure | 10‚Å¥ ‚Äì 10‚Å∂ |
| Coating | Sagging & leveling | 10¬≥ ‚Äì 10‚Åµ |
| Fiber spinning | Melt strength | 10‚Åµ ‚Äì 10‚Å∂ |
structural.eta0_qc:
**Hydrolysis Detection:**

TPU is very moisture-sensitive ‚Üí chain scission ‚Üí Mw drops ‚Üí Œ∑‚ÇÄ drops strongly

**Golden rule:** >20% deviation in Œ∑‚ÇÄ between batches ‚Üí investigate BEFORE processing!
structural.gn0_definition:
The **plateau modulus** is the value of G' in the elastic plateau region:

$$G_N^0 = \text{median}(G') \quad \text{where} \quad G' > 2G''$$

**Physical meaning:** Measures the density of chain entanglements.
structural.gn0_molecular:
$$G_N^0 \approx \frac{\rho R T}{M_e}$$

**Interpretation:**
- High G_N‚Å∞ ‚Üí More entanglements ‚Üí Higher melt strength
- Low G_N‚Å∞ ‚Üí Fewer entanglements ‚Üí Softer melt
structural.gn0_typical:
| Hardness | G_N‚Å∞ (Pa) | Me | Melt Strength |
|-----------|------------|-----|--------------|
| Shore 70A | 1‚Äì3√ó10‚Åµ | ~3000 | Low |
| Shore 90A | 3‚Äì6√ó10‚Åµ | ~2000 | Medium |
| Shore 60D | 6‚Äì10√ó10‚Åµ | ~1500 | High |
| Shore 75D | >10‚Å∂ | <1500 | Very high |
structural.terminal_slope_definition:
In the terminal zone (lowest frequencies, Œ¥ > 75¬∞) a Newtonian melt should satisfy:

$$G' \propto \omega^2$$
$$G'' \propto \omega^1$$
structural.terminal_slope_interpretation:
| Slope | Diagnosis | Action |
|--------|-----------|---------|
| 1.9‚Äì2.1 | Excellent | None |
| 1.7‚Äì1.9 | Slight structure | Monitor |
| 1.5‚Äì1.7 | Incomplete melt | Increase T +20¬∞C |
| <1.5 | Severe | Stop & check sample |
| >2.3 | Unusual | Check data |
structural.terminal_slope_tpu: Critical because hard segments may crystallize during measurement if temperature is too low. Always measure above hard-segment Tm + safety margin.
structural.crossover_definition:
The crossover point is where:

$$G'(\omega_{co}) = G''(\omega_{co})$$
structural.crossover_number:
| Crossovers | Interpretation |
|-------------|----------------|
| 1 | Ideal |
| 2 | Possibly bimodal |
| ‚â•3 | Complex morphology |
structural.crossover_tpu: Often caused by bimodal Mw distribution, hard-segment domains, or incompatible segment blends.
structural.crossover_process:
**High œâ_co:** Fast relaxation, easy filling, low stability
**Low œâ_co:** Slow relaxation, high melt strength, higher pressure

calc.intro: Fast engineering calculators to translate rheological parameters into practical processing metrics.
calc.shear_rate_intro: Estimate shear rate from screw speed or flow conditions.
calc.shear_rate_extrusion_params:
- **D**: Screw diameter (m)
- **N**: Rotation speed (rev/s)
- **h**: Channel depth (m)
calc.shear_rate_typical:
| Process | Shear Rate (1/s) |
|----------|------------------|
| Rotational rheometer | 0.01 ‚Äì 100 |
| Extrusion | 10 ‚Äì 1000 |
| Injection molding | 1000 ‚Äì 10000 |
calc.mw_intro: Estimate molecular weight change from zero-shear viscosity ratio.
calc.mw_example:
If Œ∑‚ÇÄ drops from 400k to 200k Pa¬∑s:

Mw ratio ‚âà (0.5)^(1/3.4) ‚âà 0.82 ‚Üí **18% Mw loss**
calc.mw_warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Valid mainly for linear polymers without strong branching. For TPU treat as trend indicator, not absolute value.
calc.ttspredict_intro: Estimate aT at a new temperature using fitted model parameters.
calc.ttspredict_note: Use only within the validated temperature window. Extrapolation increases error quickly.
calc.viscosity_intro: Estimate viscosity at a target shear rate using a power-law approximation.
calc.viscosity_powerlaw_params:
- **K**: Consistency index
- **n**: Flow index (n < 1 = shear thinning)
calc.viscosity_interpretation:
| n | Behavior |
|----|-----------|
| 1.0 | Newtonian |
| 0.7‚Äì0.9 | Mild shear thinning |
| 0.4‚Äì0.7 | Strong shear thinning |
| <0.4 | Very strong shear thinning |
rule_of_thumb_list: Measure at least 5 temperatures for reliable TTS modeling
Choose T_ref near your main processing temperature
Negative WLF C1 ‚Üí TTS not valid in this range
Œ∑‚ÇÄ change > 20% between batches ‚Üí investigate material history
Multiple crossovers ‚Üí check morphology or Mw distribution
R¬≤ < 0.95 for shift fit ‚Üí use results with caution
calc.quick_diagnostics:
| Observation | Likely Cause | Recommended Action |
|--------------|--------------|--------------------|
| Curves don‚Äôt overlap after TTS | Not thermo-simple | Limit T range |
| Œ∑‚ÇÄ very low | Degradation / hydrolysis | Check drying |
| Terminal slope too low | Not fully molten | Increase T |
| WLF fit unstable | Wrong T_ref | Move T_ref higher |
| Large batch spread | Mw variation | Add QC screening |

interpretation_guide.main_intro: Use this guide to translate rheological results into material behavior and processing risk. Each indicator helps you decide whether your TPU is suitable for processing and how reliable your measurements are.
interpretation_guide.quality_flags_intro: Automatic indicators based on fitted parameters and curve behavior.
interpretation_guide.flag_green_desc:
Data and fits are physically consistent.
- TTS valid
- Model fit strong
- Parameters in expected range
- Suitable for quantitative decisions
interpretation_guide.flag_yellow_desc:
Mostly usable but with warnings.
- Moderate fit quality
- Small physical inconsistencies
- Limited temperature window
- Use for trends, not absolutes
interpretation_guide.flag_red_desc:
Results likely not physically valid.
- TTS breakdown
- Non-physical parameters
- Poor fit quality
- Do not use for process decisions
tts_validation_list: No visible phase transitions in test window
interpretation_guide.tts_validation_rule: If 2 or more checks fail ‚Üí treat TTS as NOT valid.

eta0_ranges.title: Zero-Shear Viscosity (Œ∑‚ÇÄ)
eta0_ranges.low: Very low ‚Üí Possible degradation or low molecular weight
eta0_ranges.normal: Normal ‚Üí Expected Mw and drying OK
eta0_ranges.high: Very high ‚Üí High Mw or partial crosslinking risk

ea_ranges.title: Activation Energy (Ea)
ea_ranges.high: > 120 kJ/mol ‚Üí Strong temperature sensitivity, narrow process window

wlf_ranges.title: WLF Parameters
wlf_ranges.c1_negative: C1 negative ‚Üí Physically invalid ‚Üí TTS breakdown
wlf_ranges.c2_extreme: C2 very high/low ‚Üí Wrong T_ref or phase effects

curve_terminal.title: Terminal Zone
curve_terminal.good: G' slope ‚âà 2 and G'' slope ‚âà 1 ‚Üí Fully molten
curve_terminal.bad: Slope too low ‚Üí Incomplete melting or structure present

curve_plateau.title: Plateau Region
curve_plateau.absent: No plateau ‚Üí Low Mw or weak entanglement

curve_crossover.title: Crossover Behavior
curve_crossover.multiple: Multiple crossovers ‚Üí Complex morphology or Mw distribution

risk_pressure.title: High Pressure Risk
risk_pressure.rule: Œ∑‚ÇÄ high + low crossover frequency ‚Üí High pressure required

risk_sagging.title: Sagging Risk
risk_sagging.rule: Low G_N‚Å∞ + fast relaxation ‚Üí Shape instability

risk_instability.title: Flow Instability Risk
risk_instability.rule: Very strong shear thinning (n < 0.4) ‚Üí Melt fracture risk

risk_degradation.title: Degradation Risk
risk_degradation.rule: Œ∑‚ÇÄ drop + Ea drop ‚Üí Possible hydrolysis or chain scission

temperature_selection_rules: Prefer highest measured temperature if WLF unstable
Keep inside measured window when possible
interpretation_guide.fit_residuals:
Random residuals ‚Üí Good model choice
Systematic curvature ‚Üí Wrong model
interpretation_guide.final_decision_tree:
```
Parameters physical?
   ‚îú‚îÄ no ‚Üí Reject model
   ‚îî‚îÄ yes
        ‚îÇ
        TTS valid?
        ‚îú‚îÄ no ‚Üí Use per-temperature data only
        ‚îî‚îÄ yes
             ‚îÇ
             Fit quality good?
             ‚îú‚îÄ no ‚Üí Use trends only
             ‚îî‚îÄ yes ‚Üí Safe for process prediction
```

fit.fit_insufficient: Not enough data points for fit

analysis.upload_intro: Upload your rheology measurement file to start the analysis.

tooltips.reference_temp: Temperature where aT = 1 and no horizontal shift is applied
tooltips.shift_model: Model used to describe temperature dependence of aT
tooltips.terminal_zone: Lowest frequency region where melt should be Newtonian
tooltips.plateau_region: Frequency region where G' is approximately constant
tooltips.r2: Coefficient of determination ‚Äî goodness of fit

report.intro: This report summarizes the rheological analysis, fitted models, and processing interpretation.

warnings.tts_invalid: TTS not fully valid ‚Äî results per temperature are more reliable

report.summary_text: The material shows {behavior_summary}. The fitted model is {model}. Parameter confidence is {confidence_level}. Processing risk level is {risk_level}.

footer.note: This report is an engineering aid and does not replace material qualification testing.
